- A seminar on diversification in tobacco growing areas was held in Florianppolis, from 5 to 7 June 2017. The event was organized by the Special Secretariat for Family Agriculture and Agrarian Development (SEAD) and Executive Secretariat of the National Commission for the Implementation of the Framework Convention for Tobacco Control, with the support of the Secretariat of the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control of the World Health Organization. Solid collective reactions were carried out by a group of social actors engaged and committed to this important and urgent issue for Brazilian society.
- Work and research plans of interest to article 17 are being prepared for its improvement .
- Political and technical visits, as well as interlocutions of interest to article 17 were carried out in the National Congress.
column4:
The ministry of Agrarian Development (MDA) contracts public and private extension entities through public calls to provide technical assistance and rural extension services for family farmers with the aim of promoting diversification of areas cultivated with tobacco.
On 2013 MDA contracted extension services to assist 11.200 tobacco producers in the Southern States of Rio Grande do Sul, Santa Catarina and Paraná, where is concentrated 98% of tobacco for cigarettes produced in Brazil.
These are 3 years contracts and include subjects related to “diversification of production and income, commercialization, value adding, farmer organization, and others related to the FCTC, such as, the health of tobacco producers, protection and conservation of natural resources, and awareness raising about the objectives of the FCTC. 
Apart from the contracts on diversification, MDA also contracted extension services on municipalities that produce tobacco, to assist another 33.400 families on other topics such as, agroecology, dairy activities, coffee production, and sustainability.
Furthermore, it has a specific item on its budget that supports training of farmers and extension agents, implementation of demonstration units on economic viable alternatives to tobacco, and research concerning diversification.
column5:
The National Program for Activities Diversification in Tobacco Growing Areas under the coordination of the Ministry of Agrarian Development (MDA ) was launched in 2005. It aims to reduce the tobacco growers economic dependence on tobacco productive chain by supporting the implementation of projects of rural extension . training and research to implement strategies for productive diversification that create new opportunities for income generation and quality of life for families .Its principles are associated with a systemic view of the famrs . with actions to strengthen sustainable development . enhance the food security of families . adopt diversified production systems that mobilize the effective participation of families including youth and women in the planning process promoting community cooperatives and association to guarantee market for new products..The Program is managed collectively and held by the institutions that comprise the Thematic Network of Diversification in Tobacco growing Family Farming. .By 2012 the program was invested more than 12 million US dollars to provide Technical Assistance and Rural Extension ( Ater ) . training and research to generate references for the diversification process Between 2011 and 2012. 75 projects were implemented in 6 tobacco growing states ( RS . SC . PR . BA . AL and SE ) in partnership with 50 NGOs and civil society . universities . research centers . associations of producers . benefiting more than 55 000 families . In 2012 . the Ministry of Agrarina Development launched a specific call for projects of Ater to promote diversification in tobacco growing areas prioritizing 95 major tobacco growing municipalities. benefiting 10.000 households producing tobacco . with investments of over 5 million US dollars.
In 2012 MDA sponsored a survey on the situation of tobacco farmers in the tobacco supply chain and their interest to shift for other crops or activities.

column3:
Taking into account the changed economic and social and institutional environment and its influence on the tobacco producers, the main strategic objective of Bulgaria is formulated in the following way to support local communities in areas where tobacco is the main livelihood by creating preconditions for sustainable development of the sector first, and second, to diversify the local economy. Two priorities have been defined to implement this strategic goal:
-Creating prerequisites for sustainable tobacco production, adapted to market changes
-Diversification of agricultural production and development of industrial activities by industry and services to create new jobs.
column5:
Tobacco growers are supported under the Rural development program in two directions: 
• Diversification into non-agricultural activities in rural areas; 
• Diversification into other agronomic activities within the farm.

column3:
Tobacco Transition Program:

In 2009, Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada introduced the Tobacco Transition Program, which was aimed at removing the outdated tobacco quota system in Ontario. The program also included funds to help tobacco growing regions of Southern Ontario to transition to a non-tobacco economy.

This program is now completed and the quota system has been removed.  

Current Grant and Contribution Programming:

At this time there are no tobacco specific federal only grant and contribution programs administered by Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada. Moreover, there are no cost-shared tobacco specific programs being delivered by provinces and territories under Canada’s current national agriculture policy framework (Growing Forward 2), under which the federal-provincial-territorial governments share the costs of a wide range of agricultural programs. 

However, as agricultural producers, tobacco producers are eligible to receive funding from a number of Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada’s programs, according to each program’s eligibility criteria. The list of such programs can be found on Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada’s web site at: http://www.agr.gc.ca/eng/programs-and-services/list-of-programs-and-services/?id=1362151577626.
column4:
Tobacco Transition Program:

In 2009, Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada introduced the Tobacco Transition Program, which was aimed at removing the outdated tobacco quota system in Ontario. The program also included funds to help tobacco growing regions of Southern Ontario to transition to a non-tobacco economy.

This program is now completed and the quota system has been removed.  

Current Grant and Contribution Programming:

At this time there are no tobacco specific federal only grant and contribution programs administered by Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada. Moreover, there are no cost-shared tobacco specific programs being delivered by provinces and territories under Canada’s current national agriculture policy framework (Growing Forward 2), under which the federal-provincial-territorial governments share the costs of a wide range of agricultural programs. 

However, tobacco producers are eligible to participate in Canada’s suit of agricultural Business Risk Management (BRM) programs (i.e., AgriInsurance, AgriStability and AgriInvest).

Tobacco producers, companies, or associations would be eligible to apply to AFFCs non-BRM programs.  However, their application would need to merit program requirements, and be aligned with the objectives of existing non-BMR programs.  No application s have been received to date under the current non-BMR programs which started in 2013.
column5:
Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada (AAFC) does not have programs specifically targeted to tobacco producers. 
Tobacco producers. including producers in transition. may however qualify for support under AAFC suite of Business Risk Management programs. For instance. the AgriInvest program could be used to make investments in alternative measures while the AgriStability program could support the adjustments towards a new situation. Tobacco producers. including producers in transition. or their respective industry associations may also qualify for support to transition from tobacco production under one of the three federal-only Growing Forward 2 programs administered by AAFC: AgriInnovation. AgriCompetitiveness and AgriMarketing.

column3: 全国种烟面积、烟叶收购量逐年减少，种烟面积从2013年的2092万亩，下降到2015年的1609.9万亩，2017年进一步下降到1482.2万亩，比2013年下降29.1%，比2015年下降7.9%；烟叶收购量从2013年的253万吨，下降到2015年的220万吨，2017年进一步下降到188.25万吨，比2013年下降25.6%，比2015年下降14.4%。我国始终坚持促进烟农增收工作举措，一方面持续加强烟叶生产基础设施建设和水源工程建设，加大先进适用技术集成和推广应用，稳步提升种植规模化、烟农职业化、服务专业化、作业机械化水平；另一方面大力推进设施资源综合利用、多元经营和辅助产业发展，积极拓宽烟农增收渠道，2017年全国烟农增加非烟收入148亿元，约占烟农总收入的20.8%，有效弥补因烟叶种植面积下降而减少的收入，带动5万余户烟农脱贫致富。
column4: 致力提升农村基础设施综合配套水平，推进水源工程援建工作，创新生产组织形式，提高专业化服务水平和机械化作业率，推广先进适用技术，精准实施产业扶贫，帮助烟农转产，促进经济社会发展。全国烟叶种植面积从2013年的2092万亩下降到2015年的1609.9万亩，减少23.04%。

column3:
El Ministerio de Agricultura destinó recursos por valor de $2.500 millones de pesos colombianos, equivalentes a 820.000 dólares para apoyar Fortalecimiento de los cultivos de maíz, fríjol, mandarina y aguacate como alternativas de rotación y diversificación del cultivo de tabaco en las principales zona tabacaleras.

En el marco de la política sectorial, Colombia cuenta con un instrumento denominado de parafiscalidad, consistente en aportes de los productores del cultivo de tabaco, para ser destinados a programas definidos por normas internas, tales como:

•	Inversión en infraestructura física y social 
•	Modernización y diversificación de la producción
•	Investigación, asistencia técnica, transferencia de transferencia de tecnología y capacitación a productores
•	Apoyo a programas de reforestación y protección de fuentes hídricas.

En Colombia las siembras de tabaco se hacen en rotación con cultivos transitorios como maíz y fríjol con el fin de aumentar el ingreso de los cultivadores y contribuyendo a la conservación del medio ambiente y mejora de la oferta alimentaria de las familias.
column4:
La implementación está enmarcada en las directrices del Convenio, y Colombia, al igual que los demás países Parte del CMCT, se encuentra en el proceso de adelantar los proyectos e iniciativas que permitan tener la información pertinente del sector. Tales estudios y datos brindarán la información para construir un plan de trabajo mancomunado con otras instituciones y países, para implementar, en ese contexto, lo pertinente al Convenio Marco.

El Gobierno, y en especial el Ministerio de Agricultura y Desarrollo Rural, ha dispuesto de diferentes instrumentos para el sector tales como el Fondo Nacional del Tabaco, el cual permite cofinanciar con recursos del nivel nacional, departamental y municipal, proyectos y programas enfocados al mejoramiento socioeconómico de los productores y trabajadores del sector (vivienda, saneamiento básico, construcción de drenajes y riego, infraestructura de secado del tabaco, modernización y diversificación del cultivo, manejo de recursos naturales y medio ambiente, seguros, etc.). Así mismo, se adelantan proyectos encaminados a apoyar los cultivos de rotación de tabaco con cultivos como maíz y fríjol, que contribuyen al mejoramiento de los ingresos de los cultivadores de tabaco.
column5: El artículo 17 (Apoyo a actividades alternativas económicamente viables) aún no cuenta con directrices aprobadas por las Partes. Se espera para el 2015 se pueda contar con directrices parciales aprobadas que permitan una primera orientación del trabajo que deberá realizar cada país.

column3:
Desde 1999 con la apertura comercial se redujo el área de siembra, para el 2014 en el país se cultivaron 33 hectáreas que se usa para la producción de puros artesanal.  Por otra parte a partir de esa década se da la reconversión del uso del suelo hacia el cultivo de piña, caña de azúcar, café y ganadería. 

Solo hay 2 industrias del tabaco en Costa Rica: Tabacalera Costarricense Sociedad Anónima, Philip Morris International (PMI), que manufactura cigarrillos para el consumo nacional. Cuenta con aproximadamente 350 empleados y tiene su planta de producción en La Rivera de Belén Heredia y la Britsh American Tobacco Central América S.A. (BACTA), cuya sucursal de Costa Rica es oficina regional de la empresa, que se encargan de coordinar las labores de Mercadeo, Finanzas, Recursos Humanos, Tecnología y Asuntos Corporativos de las operaciones en el área. Solo hay venta y distribución de cigarrillos, cuenta con 275 empleados y se ubica en San Joaquín de Flores, Heredia.

En cuanto a los pequeños vendedores (pulperías-puestos-supermercados y otros) estos deben cumplir con las indicaciones de la Ley General de Control de Tabaco y sus efectos nocivos en la Salud para poder comercializar cualquier producto de Tabaco.
column4:

column3:
Según el Ministerio de Industrias y Productividad (MIPRO), aproximadamente 650 agricultores independientes cultivan tabaco para las empresas tabacaleras en el país, principalmente en las provincias de Guayas y Los Ríos y se calcula que se siembran las siguientes clases de tabaco: Virginia, 800 a 1.000 ha/año. Burley, 300 ha/año. Con estas dos clases se elaboran los cigarrillos rubios y tabaco de capa (1.000 ha/año). El Ministerio de Agricultura y Ganadería (MAG), maneja programas o proyectos de apoyo relacionados al fomento de diversos cultivos para suplir el cultivo de tabaco.
El MIPRO estima que más de 500 personas trabajan en las tres empresas del país productoras de tabaco (ITABSA, TANASA, PROESA). Asimismo, esta Cartera de Estado no ha trabajado puntualmente en alternativas para redireccionar a la gente involucrada en esta industria hacia otras opciones. 
Sin embargo, se ha venido trabajando en un portafolio de proyectos los cuales comprenden cacao, café, pesca y lácteos, por lo que se podría coordinar propuestas que encadenen o anclen a esta fuerza laboral en otras cadenas productivas agroindustriales que se están fortaleciendo e incluso innovando en el país.
Según el MIPRO, el desplome del consumo de tabaco nacional ha provocado que algunos agricultores ya no tengan cupos de compra y a otros desde el año 2016 les redujeron la superficie de siembra, resultando en que un porcentaje de agricultores de tabaco cambien su producción a cadenas de valor bien cimentadas como el cacao, ya que la constante alza de la demanda y el precio   le convierten en la alternativa de producción más viable. En varias zonas de Milagro y Jujan los ex tabacaleros se volcaron a la pepa, siendo una solución viable que debería ser impulsada por el MAG, anclada al perfeccionamiento de propuestas que se han venido trabajando por parte del MIPRO, con el fin de fortalecer y beneficiar la cadena del cacao y por ende necesitar de mayores superficies de siembra y por supuesto de fuerza laboral.

column4: Ministry of Health & family Welfare has written to Ministry of Agriculture to examine the proposal  of Barn Buyout scheme suggested by the Ministry of Commerce. The scheme envisages to provide financial support to FCV tobacco growers to phase out from FCV tobacco cultivation in India.
column5:
Ministry of Health & Family Welfare organised a meeting of the Agriculture Secretaries of the major tobacco producing states. During the workshop Secretary (Health & family Welfare) urged these states to work out alternative schemes for tobacco growers.
As a follow–up Secretary (Health & Family Welfare) also wrote to the District Magistrate of the concerned  district to take up the issue of alternative livelihood. 
A “National Consultation on Tobacco Economics” was organized by the Ministry on 20-21 December. 2012. The consultation dwelt into the three issues of economics of tobacco. i.e.(i) Health Cost of Tobacco Use. (ii) Alternative livelihood to tobacco farmers and bidi rollers and (iii) tobacco taxation. It involved Ministry of Finance and other relevant Ministries like Commerce. Agriculture. Labor. Rural Development & Environment. the state Governments. United Nations (UN) agencies like ILO. FAO. UNDP. IFAD and World Bank etc. National Consultation provided a good opportunity to engage with the State Governments and bring them on board for the economics of tobacco w.r.t tobacco taxation and alternative livelihood to tobacco growers and tobacco workers. The consultation has also come up with a series of recommendation.

column5:
Based on Article 18 of the executive bylaw of the national tobacco control law Iran Tobacco Company is obligated to comply with national standards in production and supply of tobacco products. Production and import of tobacco products in breach of standards set in the relevant laws and the present bylaw and related instructions is forbidden. Iran Tobacco Company should determine the surface area of tobacco plantation based on the need of domestic factories with a good programming coordinated with the Headquarters and should prevent any increase in the area of tobacco cultivation in excess of the need of domestic factories with the help of Law Enforcement Department (Police).
Ministry of Agriculture Jihad and Ministry of Industry and Mines are obligated to study and enforce the gradual replacement of tobacco farming with other agricultural products in the fanning pattern of areas where tobacco is produced and processed in case the need to tobacco in domestic factories diminishes.
According to the note of this article subsidizing the cultivation growth and harvest of tobacco is not allowed in any manner.
According to reports received from concerned authorities about 17 000 hectares (6000 Acre for cigarette tobacco and 11000 for Waterpipe tobacco) of agricultural land devoted to tobacco cultivation which supplied a small fraction of domestic demand. 
Currently the Ministry of Agriculture announced its readiness for alternationprovided that the tobacco company suspend its support to tobacco cgrowers in terms of financial and technicallly.

The anti-smoking law No. (19) of 2012 requires to provide support for economically viable alternative activities through Mayati: 
Organizing awareness programs for farmers to grow crops useful to society instead of tobacco cultivation. 
As well as indicate the executive instructions of the law to Mayati: 
1. Identifying tobacco-growing areas in Iraq. 
2. Not to give any support or facilities to the farmers for the cultivation of tobacco crop and non-crop purchase by the state. 
3. Encourage farmers and give them the facilities and assistance for the purpose of alternative crops for tobacco crop to be more useful.

column3: Italy is a Member State of the European Union and the public policies in the field of agriculture and associated businesses are decided at EU level directly implementing in each Member state the Regulations of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). Since crop year 2010 no subsidy is paid to tobacco growers both on a compulsory and on a voluntary basis. On the other side no specific measure exist to support the diversion of tobacco growers to alternative crop or activity but tobacco growers, like any other farmers have access to the Rural Development programmes measures. No support measure is foreseen for tobacco workers (meaning cultivation and first processing, tobacco manufacturing does not exist anymore in Italy since 2003). Individual Tobacco sellers does not exist in Italy

column4:
Pakistan is a member of working group formed on Article 17&18 of FCTC. Pakistan participated in Fourth meeting of the working group on economically sustainable alternatives to tobacco growing in relation to Articles 17 and 18 of the WHO. Keeping in view the recommendations of this working group, Pakistan is planning to take the following measures:
•	Research on alternate crop cycles that are economically viable for farmers
•	Marketing mechanisms for the new crops
•	Subsidy to farmers to grow alternate crops
•	Capacity building of farmers regarding new crops
•	Media/ info campaigns to educate farmers
column5:
Pakistan is a member of working group formed on Article 17&18 of FCTC. Pakistan has participated in Fourth meeting of the working group on economically sustainable alternatives to tobacco growing in relation to Articles 17 and 18 of the WHO from 18 - 20 February 2014 at Geneva. Keeping in view the recommendations of this working group Pakistan is planning to take the following measures:
•	Research on alternate crop cycles that are economically viable for farmers
•	Marketing mechanisms for the new crops
•	Subsidy to farmers to grow alternate crops
•	Capacity building of farmers regarding new crops
•	Media/ info campaigns to educate farmers

Panamá no es productor de hojas de tabaco a gran escala y cada vez más se reducen las hectáreas sembradas, recientemente se público una noticia que indicaba que los pequeños cultivos de tabaco en Dolega han sido reemplazados por plantaciones de palmas aceiteras. De hecho, le  cultivo y fabricación de productos de tabaco  no es considerado para estimar su contribución al PIB. 
Existe un fabrica de cigarrillos para la exportación  denominada Overseas United S.A que opera en una área comercial especial (zona aduanera) pero toda su materia prima es importada.

En estos momentos el artículo 17 continúa sin ser una prioridad nacional.

column4: Through the South-South and Triangular Cooperation Meeting for the implementation of the WHO FCTC, the Philippines was selected as a Technical Assistance Recipient for Article 17 and 18. Feedback had been made to the relevant Article 17 National Tobacco Control Committee. A team composed of representatives from the Department of Agriculture, Department of Agrarian Reform, Department of Labor and Employment and the Department of Health, including representatives from the Regional Health Office and Agricultural Office had been organized to travel to Brazil to study their Alternative Livelihood Program. It is expected that the Philippine team will develop a proposed country specific project on Alternative Livelihood for Tobacco Farmers.

The EU legislation allows possibility of transitional granting payments, unrelated to the production, in the tobacco sector. Poland took advantage of this possibility in order to prevent sudden and significant reduction of the help in this sector. In the EU legislation degressive character of the transitional domestic support was established to 2020.

2. The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development appealed to scientific research institutes in order to undertake examinations aimed at implementation of other, economically effective, manners of running an agricultural households where the cultivation of the tobacco plant constitutes the main cultivation.

3. There are some possibilities of supporting tobacco growers as a part of the Rural Development Programme for period of 2014-2020, which is based on provisions the EU, in particular on Regulation of the European Parliament and Council No. 1305 /2013 on the rural development support by the European Agricultural Fund for the Development of Rural Areas (EFRROW). The main goal of the mentioned programme for 2014-2020 is an improvement of competitiveness of agriculture and sustainable territorial development of rural areas. Supporting producers of tobacco in Poland will be possible in frames of the following instruments: Bonuses for young farmers, Restructuring project of small households, Modernization of agricultural households, Establishing groups and organisations of producers.
There has been no progress to date.

column4:
According to the National Strategy of Agriculture and Rural Development (2014) agricultural workers are free to choose the type of culture they would like to cultivate. The Ministry of Agriculture does not introduce any measure to encourage agricultural workers to any kind of herbal production.
Since 2012, tobacco production has been integrated into the general system of subsidies for herbal production through direct payment per hectare of farmland. The production of tobacco itself has not been additionally subsidized.
column5: Since 2012 tobacco production has been integrated into the general system of subsidies for herbal production through direct payments per hectare of farmland. The production of tobacco itself has not been additionally subsidized.

There is no Government programme or policy to actively promote economically viable alternatives for tobacco workers growers and individual sellers. Possible alternatives for tobacco growers exist but have not been promoted.

column4:
En España, se pueden distinguir dos tipos de apoyo a la diversificación del cultivo del tabaco: ayudas nacionales y ayudas cofinanciadas por Fondo Europeo Agrícola de Desarrollo Rural (FEADER).
1.	Ayudas nacionales: Ayudas a la diversificación y dinamización económica de municipios tabaqueros. En 2013, En Extremadura se convocó una ayuda dotada de 8.500.000 euros (Decreto 42/2013, de 26 de marzo, por el que se establecen las bases reguladoras de la concesión de ayudas para la diversificación y dinamización económica de municipios tabaqueros, y se dispone la convocatoria para el ejercicio 2013). El sector primario está excluido de esta ayuda y están incluidos los sectores secundario y terciario. Se han aprobado 228 expedientes.
El 10 de octubre de 2011, se suscribió un  convenio de colaboración entre el Ministerio de Medio Ambiente y Medio Rural y Marino y la Consejería de Agricultura, Desarrollo Rural, Medio Ambiente y Energía de la Junta de Extremadura, para la realización de un programa de desarrollo rural sostenible en las comarcas tabaqueras extremeñas. El convenio de suscribió como consecuencia de la inclusión en la Ley 39/2010, de 22 de diciembre, de presupuestos Generales del Estado para el año 2011 como una subvención nominativa, con una dotación de 9.000.000 de euros. A fin de desarrollar las actuaciones descritas en el convenio, la Consejería de Agricultura estableció mediante el Decreto 42/2013, de 26 de marzo, las bases reguladoras para la concesión de ayudas en concurrencia competitiva, para la diversificación y dinamización económica de municipios con clara vocación tabaquera, así como en su área de influencia.
El convenio, con un acuerdo de modificación y prórroga incluido, terminó el 31 de diciembre de 2014, en estos momentos la Comisión de Seguimiento del convenio está gestionando su cierre y liquidación.
Al amparo del convenio se han certificado 167 expedientes suponiendo un gasto con cargo al convenio de 5.705.893,07 de euros, incluyendo una asistencia técnica para la realización, entre otros, de trabajos de apoyo a la gestión de la línea de ayudas a la diversificación y dinamización económica de los municipios tabaqueros con un coste de 259.557,57 euros, la diferencia entre la dotación inicial del convenio (9.000.000 de euros) y la cantidad justificada se devolverá por parte de la Junta de Extremadura al Tesoro Público. 
2.	Ayudas cofinanciadas por el FEADER: Existen tres programas de desarrollo rural (PDR) FEADER que contienen ayudas a la diversificación del tabaco: Castilla y León, Andalucía y Extremadura.
Andalucía: El Programa de Desarrollo Rural (PDR) de Andalucía, para el marco 2007-2013, recogía la Medida 144 "Explotaciones en proceso de reestructuración con motivo de la reforma de la OCM del tabaco", que tenía como beneficiarios a los tabaqueros que realizaran una diversificación económica hacia otras actividades tanto agrarias como no agrarias. Esta medida tenía una financiación asignada de un gasto público que ascendía a un montante de 1.584.606 euros para el marco 2007-2013.
No obstante, el actual Programa de Desarrollo Rural (PDR) de Andalucía, en su marco 2014-2020, no recoge operaciones específicas destinadas a la diversificación del sector del tabaco.
Extremadura: Los proyectos de diversificación del sector tabaquero se incluyen en el PDR 2007-2013 de Extremadura dentro de la medida 413 (aplicación de estrategias de desarrollo local), que comprendía  actividades de diversificación hacia actividades no agrícolas, ayuda a la creación y desarrollo de microempresas y fomento de actividades turísticas. Toda la medida 413 tiene una asignación financiera de 10.607.903 euros (en este montante se incluye tanto las actuaciones dirigidas al sector tabaquero como a otros sectores).
Castilla y León: En el periodo 2012-2014 se apoyó la reconversión de las explotaciones que iniciaran otra actividad con abandono progresivo del cultivo del tabaco.
En la actualidad no se concede ayuda alguna en este ámbito.

A raíz del cierre de la fábrica elaboradora de cigarrillos de Philip Morris, se ha producido la reconversión de un grupo de sus trabajadores, los cuales han constituído una cooperativa de trabajo (Cooperativa 21 de Octubre) actualmente dedicada al control de tabaco, en tareas de información a la población y de  fiscalización de la normativa vigente.
За последние два года прогресс отсутствует

Following the baseline baseline survey conducted by the Zambia Agriculture Research Institute and Tobacco Free Association of Zambia, on identification of Alternative Crops to Tobacco Cultivation in tobacco growing regions of Zambia, a series of  consultative meetings with small scale tobacco farmers on Alternative Crops where held.  The alternative crops identified that need support include; soyabeans, cotton, beans, upland rice, sunflower and vegetable production. Livestock based  interventions with potential for short term household income needs such as, fish farming and small scale dairy where also identified.
